ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot about discussing works in a seminar based class, which I really enjoyed. I like how supportive this class was; nothing was too stupid and everything was accepted as legit no matter how crazy it sounds.
Learned so much about what it means to consume literature from colonial and postcolonial contexts.

I gained the skills to more deeply discuss non-canonical literature, particularly in terms of exploring the impact that unorthodox forms and techniques have on a reader. I was also exposed to a lot of really interesting writing I wouldn't have found myself outside of this course.
Reading many texts and perspectives on decolonization; postcolonial literature.

- How to better analyze literature based on its author's identity, audience, publisher, and historical context
- A new perspective on analytical papers (thinking about them more creatively rather than writing based on a set thesis)
- What constitutes as 'English' (e.g. Claude McKay's poems in patois and Cathy Park Hong's very own, made-up language in Dance Dance Revolution)

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Maybe more organized homework assignments/reading assignments would be helpful; sometimes they get posted the day of class and I do not have time to read them.
Ernest is by far the best professor to take this course with. Everyone in the class adored him and it was a wonderful time.

Strengths: Professor Mitchell is charismatic, caring, and helpful during office hours. He really does a lot to help you figure things out with your own intuition rather than simply telling you all the answers.
Weaknesses: classes usually began a bit late and readings were often not posted until the last minute.

Strengths:
- Loved the syllabus
- Prof. Mitchell really lets students take the lead in discussions but provides helpful background context with necessary
- For our analytical papers, Prof. Mitchell placed a strong emphasis on the process of writing rather than the finished product or the grade. I feel like I grew significantly as a writer because of this

Weaknesses:
- Readings were sometimes posted a day before class

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, absolutely, but only with Ernest. I think that other professors have a lot to learn about how to structure their pedagogy from him, especially in these foundational English courses.
In a heartbeat. It's great for anyone who wants to broaden their understanding of literature.

Yes! Prof. Mitchell is wonderful, and I think this course really challenges you to evaluate your own notions of what it means to be an English speaker/how to critically analyze authors from different (especially racial, cultural, and linguistic) backgrounds.
